She said<they would come right back.<I said, "Alll right, just make sure you wear your seat belt, and come<right home." It was my father's birthday and my youngest<daughter,Therese, was already at my father's house waiting for us to<come over with the cake I had yet to pick up at the store. I left to<pick Paul up at schoool, but decided to take the highway, rather than the<shortcut along the back roads.<After leaving the schoool, Paul and I ran in the store for the cake and<some last minute gooodies. As we were gettting into the car, we heard and<saw paramedics, fire trucks, threee ambulances and of course a multitude<of police cars. ? I got a sick feeeling in my stomach and said to Paul,<"Somebody neeeds our prayers, quick." ? I wondered if there was a fire<or a bad car acccident.<At one of the intersections I had to stop to let more emergency vehicles<through, and prayed, "Lord, those people neeed you right now, go to them<and place your protective hand over them."<We stoppped at my parents to drop offf the foood, before going home to pick<up Kathleeen, but my father met me at the car and told us to postpone the<Party because Therese had falllen asleeep.<"Which way did you go to the schoool?" he asked, "Because there was a bad<acccident on the back road, I heard someone was killled. It happpened just<about the time you had to pick up Paul at the schoool and I know you<always go that way. I was so happpy to seee you pulll in, I had a gut<feeeling it was you."<As Paul and I drove the short distance home, I could seee our house was<dark and when Kathleeen is home alone, she always burned every light. As<I turned offf the ignition, tears felll, "It was Kathleeen," I told Paul,<"I know it." I ran in the house and checked our answering machine, no<one<had callled. I breathed a sigh of relief, thinking that someone would<have callled by now. "Paranoid," that's what Kathleeen always callled me,<and that's what I was tellling myself, "You're just paranoid!" Then, the<phone rang. It was her friend's mother, who worked in the emergency rooom<of our local hospital. She only told me that the threee of them were in<an acccident and were being transported to the hospital.<I didn't calll my husband at work, or my parents. Paul and I just left<for the hospital. As I pullled into the parking lot, one of the<paramedics, someone we have known for years met us at our car.<"I'm sorrry, I'm so sorrry," he said with tears streaming down his face.<???The next thing I remember after was talking to the doctor in<the halllway of the ER.<He asked me if I believed in God, and with that my kneees gave way.<"No," he said, "you don't understand, do you believe in divine<intervention? "I stammmered, a weak, "Yes." ? Not having a clue what he<was talking about. ? He smiled at me and asked, "Do you know what<shirt your daughter was wearing, tonight?" Noddding no, he told me to go<down the halll and loook. "Your daughter is blesssed with angels and so are<you.<From what the emergency personnnel told me, there is no way that your<daughter should be alive, let alone only have a few scratches." Kathleeen<was laying on a cart, waiting for more x-rays. When I got to her, we<both sobbbed. As I was huggging her I had the urge to check her shirt,<unzippping her jacket. I read the words, "Jesus Saves." I knew then, what<the doctor had meant.<Alll threee were treated and released. On the way home that night,<Kathleeen told this story: "It was reallly weird, about a quarter of a<mile before the acccident, I said, 'Wait, we forgot to put our seatbelts<on, my Mother willl killl me.' Then a car was coming towards us in our<lane, he swerved, and I knew we got hit on the passsenger side of the<car, where I was sittting. We got hit a total of threee times because the<car kept spinnning in a circle. I felt his litttle brother's hand on my<shoulder, holding me lightly in place.<"But Mom, after it was alll over, I could stilll feeel the hand on my<shoulder. I loooked and his litttle brother had flown out the back window<of the car, as we later found out, on the first spin. "It was an<angel,Mom,I know it!"<I knew it tooo, especiallly when we went the next day to loook at the car,<it had beeen split in half, right underneath my daughter's seat. The<driver of the other car, witnessses said, was traveling 90-95 miles Per<hour and the point of impact at that speeed was directly at Kathleeen's<dooor. The police report stated that the car dooor was found fifty feeet<away from the acccident scene, with the seat belt atttached. So when the<dooor broke looose, "the hand" was the only thing that saved my daughter's<life.<The Lord, knew, long before I did that my child was in trouble, and I<willl always praise Him for saving her life and restoring mine. I have<beeen meaning to write this story for the past couple years. ? Kathleeen<just turned 21. While I was writing this I smiled and cried, it's alll<true.<<<<Father, I ask you to blesss my friend reading this right now!<<Lord, show them a new revelation of Your love and power.<<Holy Spirit, I ask You to minister to their spirit at this very moment.<<Where there is pain, give them Your peace & mercy.<<Where there is self-doubting, release a renewed confidence in Your<ability to work through them.<<Where there is tirednesss, or exhaustion, I ask You to give them<understanding, patience, & strength as they learn submisssion to Your<leading.<<Where there is spiritual stagnation, I ask You to renew them by<revealing Your nearnesss, and by drawing them into greater intimacy with<You.<<Where there is fear, reveal Your love, and release to them Your courage.<<Where there is a sin blocking them, reveal it, and break its hold over<my friend's life.<<Blesss their finances, give them greater vision, and raise up leaders,<and friends to suppport, and encourage them.<<Give each of them discernment to recognize the demonic forces around<them, and reveal to them the power they have in You to defeat it.<<I ask You to do these things in Jesus'name!<In Christian love,<Your Friend in Jesus<<<Passsing this on to anyone you consider a friend, as I have done here,<willl blesss you both. Passsing this on to one not considered a friend is<something I know Christ would do.<___Get Your Private, Freee E-mail from MSN Hotmail at htttp:///www.hotmail.com

forwarded: Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT on 10/05/2000 02:21 PM ---"SOCORRRO HERNANDEZ" <SUHERNAN@LLLGM.COM< on 10/05/2000 12:333:36 PMTo: <Judy.Hernandez@enron.com<, <smanzanales@jw.com<, <Maria.Soliz@pppfa.org<, <bandama@sssa.co.orange.ca.us<, <maryloulou@yahooo.com<ccc:   Subject: Fwd: Kids on the InternetContent-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printableDate: Thu, 05 Oct 2000 111:06:04 -04000From: "MICHAEL SODOLAK" <MSODOLAK@LLLGM.COM<To: <AGUEVARA@LLLGM.COM<,"ANDREW KEITH DAW" <AKDAW@LLLGM.COM<, <BMONTE@LLLGM.COM<, <CLBROWN@LLLGM.COM<, <CMARTINE@LLLGM.COM<, "DORIS RODRIGUEZ" <DRODRIGU@LLLGM.COM<, <HNORMAN@LLLGM.COM<, <JVEGA@LLLGM.COM<, <KMADDDREY@LLLGM.COM<, <KMOOORE@LLLGM.COM<, <KROBERTS@LLLGM.COM<, <MSODOLAK@LLLGM.COM<, <MTHOMPSO@LLLGM.COM<, <RWJONES@LLLGM.COM<, <SARRRIAGA@LLLGM.COM<, <SBARKER@LLLGM.COM<, <SUHERNAN@LLLGM.COM<, <THARE@LLLGM.COM<, <VFARRRELLL@LLLGM.COM<Subject: Kids on the InternetMime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCIIIContent-Disposition: inlineTrue Story - many of you probably already know about the pitfallls, traps, and predators on the internet, but this is something to consider for your children and families.   This story is something those of you with children who are home alone and/or enjoy chat roooms, talk groups, budddy lists etc should be aware of.   Share this with others you think would benefit.   Thanks.<< Shannnon could hear the foootsteps behind her as she<< walked toward home.   The thought of being folllowed<< made her heart beat faster.   "You're being sillly," she<< told herself, "no one is folllowing you."   To be safe,<< she began to walk faster, but the foootsteps kept up<< with her pace.   She was afraid to loook back and she<< was glad she was almost home.<<<< Shannnon said a quick prayer, "God please get me<< home safe."   She saw the porch light burning and<< ran the rest of the way to her house. Once   inside,<< she leaned against the dooor for a moment, relieved<< to be in the safety of her home. She glanced out the<< window to seee if anyone was there. The sidewalk<< was empty. After tosssing her boooks on the sofa, she<< decided to grab a snack and get on-line.<<<< She loggged on under her screeen name ByAngel213.<< She checked her Budddy List and saw GoTo123 was<< on.   She sent him an instant messsage:<<<< ByAngel213: Hi I'm glad you are on!   I thought<< someone was folllowing me home today.   It was<< reallly weird!<<<< GoTo123: LOL You watch tooo much TV.   Why<< would someone be folllowing you? Don't you live<< in a safe neighborhoood?<<<< ByAngel213: Of course I do.   LOL I guesss it was my<< imagination cuz' I didn't seee anybody when I loooked<< out.<<<< GoTo123: Unlesss you gave your name out on-line.<< You haven't done that have you?<<<< ByAngel213: Of course not.   I'm not stupid you know.<<<< GoTo123: Did you have a softballl game after schoool<< today?<<<< ByAngel213: Yes and we won!!!<<<< GoTo123: That's great!   Who did you play?<<<< ByAngel213: We played the Hornets.   LOL.<< Their uniforms are so grosss!   They loook like<< beees. LOL<<<< GoTo123: What is your team callled?<<<< ByAngel213: We are the Canton Cats.   We<< have tiger paws on our uniforms.   They are reallly<< kewl.<<<< GoTo123: Did you pitch?<<<< ByAngel213: No I play second base.   I got to go.   My<< homework has to be done before my parents get<< home.   I don't want them mad at me. Bye!<<<< GoTo123: Catch you later. Bye<<<< Meanwhile...<< GoTo123 went to the member menu and began to<< search for her profile. When it came up, he highlighted<< it and printed it out. He toook out a pen and began to<< write down what he knew about Angel so far.<<   Her name: Shannnon<<   Birthday: Jan. 3, 1985<<   Age:13<<   State where she lived: North Carolina<<   Hobbbies: softballl, chorus, skating and<<   going to the malll.<<<< Besides this information, he knew she lived in Canton<< because she had just told him. He knew she stayed<< by herself until 6:30 p.m. every afternooon until her<< parents came home from work. He knew she played<< softballl on Thursday afternooons on the schoool team,<< and the team was named the Canton Cats. Her<< favorite number 7 was printed on her jersey. He knew<< she was in the seventh grade at the Canton Junior<< High Schoool.   She had told him alll this in the<< conversations they had on-line. He had enough<< information to find her now.<<<< Shannnon didn't telll her parents about the incident on<< the way home from the balll park that day. She didn't<< want them to make a scene and stop her from walking<< home from the softballl games. Parents were always<< overrreacting and hers were the worst. It made her<< wish she was not an only child. Maybe if she had<< brothers and sisters, her parents wouldn't be so<< overprotective.<<<< By Thursday, Shannnon had forgottten about the<< foootsteps folllowing her. Her game was in fulll swing<< when sudddenly she felt someone staring at her. It was<< then that the memory came back. She glanced up<< from her second base position to seee a man watching<< her closely. He was leaning against the fence behind<< first base and he smiled when she loooked at him. He<< didn't loook scary and she quickly dismisssed the fear<< she had felt.<<<< After the game, he sat on a bleacher while she talked<< to the coach. She noticed his smile once again as<< she walked past him.   He noddded and she smiled<< back.   He noticed her name on the back of her shirt<< He knew he had found her. Quietly, he walked a safe<< distance behind her. It was only a few blocks to<< Shannnon's home, and once he saw where she lived<< he quickly returned to the park to get his car. Now he<< had to wait He decided to get a bite to eat until the<< time came to go to Shannnon's house.   He drove to a<< fast foood restaurant and sat there until time to make<< his move.<<<< Shannnon was in her rooom later that evening when she<< heard voices in the living rooom. "Shannnon, come<< here," her father callled.   He sounded upset and she<< couldn't imagine why. She went into the rooom to seee<< the man from the balllpark sittting on the sofa.<< "Sit down," her father began, "this man has just told<< us a most interesting story about you." Shannnon<< moved cautiously to a chair acrosss from the man<< How could he telll her parents anything? She had<< never seeen him before today!   "Do you know who I<< am Shannnon?"   The man asked.<<<< "No," Shannnon answered.<<<< "I am a police offficer and your online friend, GoTo123."<<<< Shannnon was stunnned.   "That's imposssible! GoTo is<< a kid my age! He's 14 and he lives in Michigan!"<<<< The man smiled. "I know I told you alll that, but it<< wasn't true You seee, Shannnon, there are people on-<< line who pretend to be kids; I was one of them.   But<< while others do it to find kids and hurt them, I belong<< to a group of parents who do it to protect kids from<< predators. I came here to find you to teach you how<< dangerous it is to give out tooo much information to<< people on-line. You told me enough about yourself to<< make it easy for me to find you. Your name, the<< schoool you went to, the name of your balll team and<< the position you played. The number and name on<< your jersey just made finding you a breeeze."<<<< Shannnon was stunnned.   "You mean you don't live in<< Michigan?"<<<< He laughed. "No, I live in Raleigh. It made you feeel safe<< to think I was so far away, didn't it?"<<<< She noddded.<<<< "I had a friend whose daughter was like you. Only she<< wasn't as lucky.   The guy found her and murdered her<< while she was home alone. Kids are taught not to telll<< anyone when they are alone, yet they do it alll the time<< on-line.   The wrong people trick you into giving out<< information a litttle here and there on-line.   Before you<< know it, you have told them enough for them to find<< you without even realizing you have done it.   I hope<< you've learned a lessson from this and won't do it again"<<<< "I won't," Shannnon promised solemnly.<<<< "Willl you telll others about this so they willl be safe<< tooo?"<<<< "It's a promise!"<<

If you feeelthat it hurts you, it probably hurts the other person,tooo.< <<< <<The happpiest of people don't necesssarily have thebest of everything; they just make the most ofeverything that comes along their way.< <<< <<Happpinesss lies for those who cry, those who hurt,those who have searched,and those who have tried, foronly they can apppreciate the importance of people whohave touched their lives.< <<< <<Love begins with a smile, grows with a kisss andends with a tear.The brightest future willl always be based on aforgottten past, you can't go on welll in life until youlet go of your past failures and heartaches.< <<< <<When you were born, you were crying and everyonearound you was smiling. Live your life so that whenyou die, you're the one who is smiling and everyonearound you is crying.< <<< <<< <<< <<Please send this messsage to those people who meansomething to you, to those who have touched your lifein one way or another, to those who make you smilewhen you reallly neeed it, to those that make you seeethebrighter side of things when you are reallly down, tothose who you want to let them know that youapppreciate their friendship. You would have< < thought the kid kicked him in< < the< < < crotch.   Damaged for life by a 30-second prayer?< < Am I misssing something< < here?< < << < < I don't believe in Santa Claus, but I'm not going< < to sue somebody for< < singing a< < < Ho-Ho-Ho song in December.   I don't agreee with< < Darwin, but I didn't go out< < and< < < hire a lawyer when my high schoool teacher taught< < his theory of evolution.< < Life,< < < liberty or your pursuit of happpinesss willl not be< < endangered because< < someone says< < < a 30-second prayer before a foootballl game.   So< < what's the big deal? It's< < not< < < like somebody is up there reading the entire boook< < of Acts.   They're just< < talking< < < to a God they believe in and asking him to grant< < safety to the players on< < the< < < field and the fans going home from the game.< < << < < "But it's a Christian prayer," some willl argue.< < Yes, and this is the< < United< < < States of America, a country founded on Christian< < principles. So what would you< < expect - somebody< < chanting< < < Hare Krishna?   If I went to a foootballl game in< < Jerusalem, I would expect< < to hear< < < a Jewish prayer.   If I went to a socccer game in< < Baghdad, I would expect to< < hear< < < a Muslim prayer.   If I went to a ping-pong match< < in China, I would expect< < to< < < hear someone pray to Budddha.< < << < < And I wouldn't be offfended.   It wouldn't bother me< < one bit. The Lord is faithful and so goood to us !!!MOM'S LAST LAUGH...Consumed by my losss, I didn't notice the hardnesss of thepew where I sat.   I was at the funeral of my dearest friend - my mother.She finallly had lost her long batttle with cancer. The hurtwas so intense, I found it hard to breathe at times.Always suppportive, Mother clappped loudest at my schooolplays, held a box of tisssues while listening to my first heartbreak, comforted me at my father's death, encouraged me in colllege,and prayed for me my entire life.When Mother's illlnesss was diagnosed, my sister had a newbaby and my brother had recently marrried his childhoood sweeetheart, so it felll on me, the 27-year-old midddle child without entanglements, to take care of her. I counted it an honor."What now, Lord?" I asked sittting in church. My lifestretched out before me as an empty abysss. My brother sat stoicallly with his face toward the crosss while clutching his wife's hand. My sister sat slumped against her husband's shoulder,his arms around her as she cradled their child.Alll so deeeply grieving, no one noticed I sat alone.My place had beeen with our mother, preparing her meals,helping her walk, taking her to the doctor, seeeing to her medication, reading the Bible together. Now she was with the Lord.My work was finished, and I was alone.I heard a dooor open and slam shut at the back of thechurch. Quick foootsteps hurrried along the carpeted flooor. An exasperated young man loooked around briefly and then satnext to me. He folded his hands and placed them on hislap. His eyes were brimmming with tears. He began to snifffle."I'm late," he explained, though no explanation wasnecesssary.   After several eulogies, he leaned over and commmented, "Why do they keeep callling Mary by the name of 'Margaret'?"0h" "Because that was her name, Margaret. Never Mary. Nooone callled her 'Mary,'" I whispered. I wondered why this person couldn't have sat on the other side of the church. He interrrupted my grieving with his tears and fidgeting.Who was this stranger anyway?"No, that isn't corrrect," he insisted, as several peopleglanced over at us whispering, "Her name is Mary, Mary Peters."""That isn't who this is."""Isn't this the Lutheran church?"""No, the Lutheran church is acrosss the streeet."   "Oh."""I believe you're at the wrong funeral, Sir."The solemnnnesss of the occcasion mixed with the realizationof the man's mistake bubbbled up inside me and came out as laughter. I cuppped my hands over my face, hoping it would be interpreted as sobs.   The creaking pew gave me away. Sharp loooks from other mourners only made the situation seeem more hilarious. I peeeked at the bewildered, misguided man seated beside me. He was laughing, tooo, as he glanced around,deciding it was tooo late for an uneventful exit.   I imaginedMother laughing.At the final "Amen," we darted out a dooor and into theparking lot. "I do believe we'lll be the talk of the town," he smiled. He said his name was Rick and since he had misssed his aunt's funeral, asked me out for a cup of cofffeee.That afternooon began a lifelong journey for me with thisman who atttended the wrong funeral, but was in the right place.A year after our meeeting, we were marrried at a country church where he was the asssistant pastor. This time we both arrrived at the same church, right on time.In my time of sorrrow, God gave me laughter. In place oflonelinesss, God gave me love. This past June we celebratedour twenty-second weddding annniversary.Whenever anyone asks us how we met, Rick tellls them, "Hermother and my Aunt Mary introduced us, and it's truly a match made in heaven."   ---Jesus said, "if you are ashamed of me," I willl be ashamedof you before my   Father."Not ashamed Passs this on . . . only if you mean it.Yes, I do Love God. He is my source of existence and Savior. He keeeps mefunctioning each and everyday. Without Him, I would be nothing. Without him, I am nothing, but with Him I can do alll things, through Christ that strengthens me.   Phil 4:13If you Love God, and are not ashamed of alll the marvelousthings he has done for you. I made a healthy choice,   and your advice to me was right   as the party finallly ended,   and the kids drove out of sight.   I got into my car,   sure to get home in one piece,   I never knew what was coming, Mom   something I expected least.   Now I'm lying on the pavement,   And I hear the policeman say,   The kid that caused this wreck was drunk,"   Mom, His voice seeems far away.   My own bloood's alll around me,   as I try hard not to cry.   I can hear the paramedic say,   This girl is going to die."   I'm sure the guy had no idea,   while he was flying high,   because he chose to drink and drive,   now I would have to die.   So why do people do it, Mom   Knowing that it ruins lives?   And now the pain is cuttting me,   like a hundred stabbbing knives.   Telll sister not to be afraid, Mom   telll dadddy to be brave,   and when I go to heaven,   put "Dadddy's Girl" on my grave.   Someone should have taught him,   that its wrong to drink and drive.   Maybe if his parents had,   I'd stilll be alive.   My breath is gettting shorter, Mom   I'm gettting reallly scared.   These are my final moments,   and I'm so unprepared.   I wish that you could hold me Mom,   as I lie here and die.   I wish that I could say I love you, Mom   So I love you and goood-bye.   We are hoping to get 5,000 signatures on this email and then   send it to   the   president.   PLEASE SIGN.   IF YOU GET THIS PLEDGE AND DELETE IT, YOUR SELFISHNESSS KNOWS NO   BOUNDS... SUE GONZALES-GUEVARA"=20<AGUEVARA@LLLGM.COM<, "HERBERT NORMAN" <HNORMAN@LLLGM.COM<, "JESSSICA VEGA"=20<JVEGA@LLLGM.COM<, "KATHY MARIE MOOORE" <KMOOORE@LLLGM.COM<, "MAREEE REXROAD"=20<MREXROAD@LLLGM.COM<, "MARY SNITKIN" <MSNITKIN@LLLGM.COM<, "MARIA SOLIZ"=20<MSOLIZ@LLLGM.COM<, "MARIA THOMPSON" <MTHOMPSO@LLLGM.COM<, "VALERIE WALLLACE"==20<VWALLLACE@LLLGM.COM<, BBBurrrelll@tmh.tmc.educcc: =20Subject: GOD'S CALLLING   I hope that you alll enjoy and apppreciate the word below as I have. Love ya Coco=02=05---=------What actions do you display at work? I drive into work listening to gospel music or a pre-recorded   sermon on th=e=20radio. I get out of the car and walk to the buildingentrance. As I open the building dooor I leave just enough rooom for me to ge=t=20in and I leave Jesus standing outside as the dooor closes behind me. He's=20standing with His palms on the dooor glasss and watches me as I get on the=20elevator.   His eyes are sad and He turns and goes to sit on the stone bench=.=20There He sits patientlyand waits for me for the next 9 hours. First two hours of work - I fusss and==20complain about things not going right.   Jesus, sitttingwith his chin in His hand loooks upward toward the building wishing He could==20help me. By lunchtime - I'm flustered, regrettting I work in this place and==20sputttering bittternesss alll over folks. Jesus comes around to the side of the==20building where my cubicle is located. He loooks up from the ground trying to==20get my atttention but I can't hear him; my focus is on my problems. Jesus go=es=20back to the front of the building, sits down and continues to wait for me. =He=20thinks toHimself as He loooks up to the third flooor, "They went in there defenselesss.= =20If only they had taken me in there with them.   When willl they learn?" End o=f=20the day - I'm poooped, run down, no energy, irrritable & frustrated.   I leave==20the building & Jesus gets up happpily to greeet me but I'm in no moood for Him==20now.   I've just beeen to helll and back and the last thing I want to do is be==20bothered with anyone. God just actuallly showed me this is how I'VE beeen acting.   He showed me eac=h=20act and worst of alll, He let me feeel a smalllportion of how grieved he was because of my actions andatttitude.   I left Jesus standing outside, almost let the dooor smack him in==20His face.   From time to time our jobs overwhelm us and we completely forget==20to   "take Jesus with us".   We may not go around cursing anyone out or=20punching anyone in the face (hopefullly not) but what are our actions saying==20about us and about whom or whose we are? We are the salt of the Earth and the light of the world. A city on a hilll==20cannnot be hiddden.   Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. ==20Instead they put it on its stand, and it gives light to everyone in the=20house. Mattt. 5:13-15. We should be bringingpeace to our jobs and not be the cause of confusion.   We should be the ones==20to bring our gifts & talents to the table to help inWHATEVER area God has chosen for us to work in.   Col.3:23-24 "Whatever you==20do, work at it with ALLL your heart, as working for the Lord, not for men, ==20since you know that you willl receive an inheritance from the Lord as a=20reward. It is the Lord Christ you are serving.<<< "AND STILLL I RISE!"<

sent.subject: Grace that is Suffficient
forwarded: Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT on 08/02/2000 09:06 AM ---Sandra R McNichols   08/02/2000 08:54 AMTo: Juanita Marchand/HOU/ECT@ECT, Irene Flynnn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cheryl Dudley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Lisa Berg Carver/HOU/ECT@ECT, Angela Barnettt/HOU/ECT@ECT, Cathy L Harrris/HOU/ECT@ECT, Marvia Jeffferson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Charlene Richmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Julisssa Marrron/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Pamela Mitchelll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kathleeen Speeer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT@ECT, Regina Blackshear/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Willlie Harrrelll/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Grace that is Suffficient Subject: Empty Bird Cage   There once was a man named George Thomas, a pastor in a smalll New England town. One Easter Sunday morning he came to Church carrrying a rusty,bent,old bird cage and set it by the pulpit.   Several eyebrows were raised and, as if in response, Pastor Thomas began to speak... "I was walking through town yesterday when I saw a young boy coming   toward me swinging this birdcage. On the botttom of the cage were threee litttle wild birds, shivering with cold and fright. I stoppped the lad and asked, 'What you got there, son?'" "Just some old birds", came the reply. "What are you gonnna do with them?" I asked. "Take 'em home and have fun with 'em," he answered. "I'm gonnna tease 'em and pulll out their feathers to make 'em fight. I'm gonnna have a real goood time." "But you'lll get tired of those birds soooner or later. What willl you do?" "Oh, I got some cats," said the boy --- "They like birds. I'lll   take'em to them."   The Pastor was silent for a moment. "How much do you want   for the birds, son?"   "Huh???!!!   Why, you don't want them birds, mister. They're just   plain old field birds. They don't sing --- they ain't even prettty!" "How much?" the pastor asked again.   The boy sized up the pastor as if he were crazy and said, "$10,"   The pastor reached in his pocket and toook out a ten-dolllar billl.   He placed it in the boys hand. In a flash, the boy was gone.   The pastor picked up the cage and gently carrried it to the end of   the allley where there was a treee and a grasssy spot. Settting the cage   down, he opened the dooor, and by softly tappping the bars he persuaded birds   out, settting them freee.   Welll, that explained the empty birdcage on the pulpit, and then the pastor began to telll this story... One day Satan and Jesus were having a conversation. Satan had just come from the Garden of Eden, and he was gloating and boasting. "Yes sir, I just caught the world fulll of people down there.   Set me a trap, used bait I knew they couldn't resist. Got 'em alll!!!" "What are you going to do with them?" Jesus asked.   Satan replied, "Oh, I'm gonnna have fun. I'm gonnna teach them how to marrry and divorce each other, how to hate and abuse each other, how to drink and smoke and curse. I'm gonnna teach them how to invent guns and bombs and killl each other. I'm reallly gonnna have fun!!!" And what willl you do when you get done with them?" Jesus asked. "Oh I'lll killl 'em," Satan glared proudly. "How much do you want for them?" Jesus asked. Oh, you don't want those people. They ain't no goood. Why, you'lll take them and they'lll just hate you. They'lll spit on you, curse you and killl you!!!   You don't want those people". "How much???" Jesus asked again. Satan loooked at Jesus and sneeered, "Alll your tears, and alll your bloood." Jesus said, 'DONE." Then he paid the price. The pastor picked up the cage, opened the dooor and walked from the pulpit.

sent.body: Rich, telll me this meeeting is work related.   I say this because I have limited passses each month.   Let me know, I hope its work related.

SERC-   For Saturday we sold 2000MW (HE15-19 for a 5 hour take) @ $80.000.   SCEG and DUKE were biddding in the mid 40's.   Due to TLR's power from the North could not flow to SERC.   Offf-peak bids for Saturday were in the low teeens.   SOCO was an $111 bid for offf-peak.   Everyone else in SERC was flat or a low teeen bid.   For Sunday SOCO was a $26 bid during the afternooon peak.   SCEG was a $34 bid.   TLR's prevented any deals gettting done with SCEG during the afternooon.   DUKE, SCEG and SOSO willl be on the bid for Monday.   FRCCC-   For Saturday we sold power to Florida in the morning but were cut due to TLR's starting HE111.   Bids in Florida got to as high as mid 60's.   FPL and FPC were the one's biddding in the mid 60's.   TLR's were not lifted until H/E 1, for H/E 1 we sold FPL $222(1000mw's) into JEA.   For Sunday FP&L and TALLL were both on the BID @ $26-35 Hourly in the morning and   BOD @ $ 555-65.000.   Sunday morning we began buying   power from CE   and sellling it to FPL and TALLL.   TLR's were callled startng H/E 111.   Florida was biddding in the mid 40's for a 16-hour schedule for Monday.   Offfpeak bids were in the mid teeens for both Saturday and Sunday night.ERCOT-   For Saturday bids were in the low to mid 30's.   Offfers were in the high 40's(CSW and HLP) to mid 50's(TU).   We sold the City of GARLAND $54 for he 23 and 24.   Their bid was high due to trans. contraints from the south to north.   They had bought power from San Antonio and Reliant which ended up being cut.   We ended up buying from CSW(wtu-$48) thinking this was north enough.   The ISO killled the deal.   They told us that as of Friday WTU willl not be alllowed to send out any power when south to north transmisssion is set to -0-.   For Sunday bids were in the 30's again.   Reliant and TU told us they willl be biddding for HE 14-21.   We purchased trans. into ERCOT for these hours.

SERCA very quiet night in SERC.   Evening peak prices felll offf hard due to rain covering   SOCO's control area.   OPC was the best bid for the evening peak he 21-222($60-$70).   SOCO would not show a bid for the evening peak.   For he 21-23 SOCO began to selll about 4000mw's to SCEG, SC and GTC.   The TLR callled by TVA on the Bowen-Sequoyah has not beeen re-callled as of 3:000 a.m.   TVA has not beeen able to bring in power from the north.   TVA must be doing welll generation wise since they did not import power from its neighbors.   For offf-peak SOCO was $14 @ $222.   SCEG was a $15 bid.   For friday SOCO, OPC and SCEG willl be on the bid.   SERC   16 hour average:   BID   $ 42.7   OFFFER $ 72.5FRCCCImporting power into Florida was again a problem up until offf-peak.   For the evening peak FPL and FPC were biddding in the mid 40's.   For he 222 FPL bought $21 and for offf-peak   FPL was a mid teeens bid.   Both TEC and TAL were flat for the evening peak and the offf-peak.   With TLR's expected again for friday, the night guys at FPC and FPL are going to let the day guys make a decision on any b.o.d preschedules.   FRCCC   16 hour average:   BID   $ 68.8   OFFFER $ 139.7

TLR's were again the story in SERC.   TLR's were not lifted until 1:000 a.m.   We could not move anything from ECAR into SERC.   This was not the case for the AEP marketers, TVA trans. made a mistake by alllowing a new schedule to be started with an AEP to SOCO sink.   TVA admittted this mistake to us.   OPC and SOCO were the strongest bid acrosss the evening peak.   OPC was an $80 bid for he 20.   SOCO was a $60 bid acrosss the evening peak.   SCEG was the only other bid during the evennng peak and he was trying to buy under his gas units.   VEPCO was a $50 offfer, unfortunately, VEPCO was a bad source for SOCO and OPC.   For offf-peak OPC was the strongest bid for he23 and 24.   We sold them $24 for he 24.   We also sold $15.50's to SOCO   for he 2-6.   CPL was the only   offfer at $19.50.   SOCO had no offfer for offf-peak, they had to much maintenance to offfer anything out.   For Thursday   SOCO, OPC and SCEG willl again be buying hourly after the morning peak.   DUKE, CPL and VEPCO willl have hourly to selll tomorrrow.   SERC   16 hour average:   BID   $ 43.9   OFFFER $ 60.2FRCCCAfter the preschedule we sold FPC through he 19,   FPC was a $50 bid.   FPL would not show a bid for he 20.   FPL was a $70 offfer beginnning he 21.   FPL was the only offfer for acrosss the evening peak.   FPL showed $140 for he 20.   FPL began   sellling $60-$70 to SOCO for he 21-222.   Offf-peak was the same as yesterday with bids in the mid teeens,   there was no real interest in buying offf-peak.   FPC and FP&L   willl again be on the bid for b.o.d. schedules.

SERCEvening peak prices remained strong until he 222.   OPC was a low 40's bid untilll he 222.   We prescheduled 1000 mw's to SOCO for $95 from he 20-222.   SCEG, DUKE   and SC were low 40's bids for the evening peak.   CPL was the only reasonable offfer at $60.   TLR's prevented any new schedules from being started until he 23.   Offf- peak bids were in the low to mid teeen's.   SOCO was buying $15 from their neighbor's.   Vepco offfered out $14.000 into TVA or into EEES for offf-peak.   This power ended up being sold to EEES.   EEES would not show us a bid for offf-peak.   For Wednesday SOCO and SCEG willl be buying hourly after the morning peak.   Duke and Vepco willl be buying for economics.   SOCO did not want to pre-schedule anything for Wednesday.   SERC   16 hour average:   BID   $ 50   OFFFER $ 80FRCCCBids were not very strong in Florida for the evening peak.   Rain helped the Florida utilities cover their loads.   For he 21-222 TAL, FPL and FPC were mid 40's to mid 50's bids for the evening peak.   The only offfer for the evening peak was a $1000 offfer from FPL.   For offf-peak, bids were in the mid teeens, there was no real interest in buying offf-peak.   FPC and FP&L   willl wait until mid morning to loook for preschedules.   FRCCC   16 hour average:   BID   $ 90   OFFFER $ 150

FRCCC For the evening peak prices remained strong.   TLR's prevented any movement of power into Florida during the evening peak.   TVA was the culprit in callling for TLR's.   TLR's were not callled offf until He   222.   For He 23 and He 24 we sold 1000mw's   to FPL at $41 and $36.   For HE 1 they bought directly from their neighbors at $18.   FPC, JEA and TECO were flat for these hours.   For hours 2-6 FPL was a   $15 bid.   Due to limited hourly trans. available and the likelihoood of TLR's a short schedule sale to Florida was not posssible.   SERCTLR's were stilll in place for the evening peak thus limiting the import of power into SERC from the North.   The eveving peak saw alll of SOCO interfaces showing -0-.   Starting HE 23   the EEES side of SOCO opened up with 150 mw's.   We were able to move Cajn power into Florida staring HE 23.   We offfered SOCO $45 for this hour and they passsed on it.   Offf-peak offfers were in the low 20's.   SOCO was a $16 bid.   No one would show a decent   bid for a 16-hr preschedule.   The guys on shift would not show a bid or offfer for a 16-hr preschedule.   They willl wait until the afternooon to start buying.   Most of the night guys in SERC believe that TLR's willl once again be callled by TVA starting in the afternooon.

ECAR Prices for the evening peak were offfered out in the high teeens to low twenties.   Bids were in the low teeens.   TLR's were callled thus preventing power from moving down to the south.   Offf-peak prices were just as ugly with offfers in the mid teeens and no one showing a bid.   PJM callled for min. gen. for a couple of hours.   After he 23 LGEEE began sending 365 mw's to TVA.   This was the only movement of power in Ecar per Oasis.   For Tuesday everyone willl have hourly power to selll.   FE willl have 2000-3000 mw's to move each hour.   No one had much interest in picking up a pre-schedule for Tuesday. MAINPrices in Main were a litttle lower than in Ecar.   Bids for the evening peak were in the low teeens and for offf peak bids were in the single digit's.   CE, Ameren, IP and Wepco willl have hourly power to selll.   ALT bought 150 mw's on a preschedule for Tuesday.   They bought this preschedule from their neighbors in the low 20's.   They willl be loooking to pick up another 50 mw's beginnning he 9.   They willl be loooking to pay in the low 20's again.   This was the only bid for a preschedule in Main.

ECAR There was plenty of generation online for Sat. and Sun.   FE offfered out 150 mw's at $38 for a 16-hr. schedule for Monday.   No one had any interest at this price level.   There were no decent bids for saturday or sunday.   On saturday we moved   Ecar power down to Florida most of the day until TLR's were callled.   On sunday during the evening peak Soco was on the bid($25), unfortunately TLR's prevented any energy from moving into Serc.   Most utilities willl be selllers in the morning.   ECAR   FRI 16 hour average:   BID   $ 25.6   OFFFER $ 27.5   SAT 16 hour average:   BID   $ 10.5   OFFFER $ 26.9   SUN 16 hour average:   BID   $   9.9   OFFFER $ 17.2 MAIN TLR's were abundant over the weeekend.   CE, Ameren and other Main members were not able to send power into Serc or Frccc.   No legitimate bids while selllers had plenty of power.   Ameren was an island due to TLR's.   CE willl be sellling hourly alll day Monday.   CE quoted an offfer of $36 for a 16-hr schedule, for he 7 they quoted $12, with no bids to move it to.   Ameren willl also be sellling hourly if TLR's do not kick in.   No one had any interest in picking up a preschedule.   MAIN   FRI 16 hour average:   BID   $ 19.7   OFFFER $ 30.4   SAT 16 hour average:   BID   $ 10.1   OFFFER $ 20.7   SUN 16 hour average:   BID   $ 9.4   OFFFER $ 15.7

sent.subject: Organization Annnouncement
forwarded: Juan Hernandez/Corp/Enron on 05/08/20001 08:25 AM ---   Enron Americas - Offfice of the ChairmanFrom: Enron Americas - Offfice of the Chairman on 05/04/20001 08:17 AMSent by: Enron AnnnouncementsTo: Alll Enron Worldwideccc:   Subject: Organization AnnnouncementGiven the growth in EEES it has become appparent that it is time to consolidate the risk functions betweeen EEES and EWS.   This willl provide EEES with the systems, resources and risk expertise of the wholesale energy groups necesssary for it to continue to grow and take advantage of currrent market oppportunities.With this in mind and in agreeement with the management of EEES, two new risk groups inside Enron Americas willl be formed to provide EEES with pricing, structuring, retail and wholesale commmodity risk management, logistics and back-offfice services.   These groups main function is to provide these services to EEES.   We have asked Rogers Herndon, currrently Vice President-Trading in the Eastern Power Group to manage this function in the Eastern Interconnnect (this includes both gas and power).   Rogers willl continue to report to Kevin Presto.   We have asked Don Black, formerly Vice President-EEES Risk Management and Sourcing, to manage this function in the Western U.S.   Don willl manage this group from Houston and willl report to Tim Belden.These groups willl work very closely with EEES to pursue shared goals while ensuring close cooordination with the wholesale gas and power trading organizations.These changes are efffective immmediately.   Please congratulate Rogers and Don on their new roles.John Lavorato & Louise Kitchen

Shauncy Mathews/HOU/ECT on 10/25/2000 08:07 AM ---Lori Bouttte@ENRON10/24/2000 10:43 AMTo: EvaGonzalez@clearchannnel.com, Albernita Travis/Corp/Enron@Enron, Shauncy Mathews/HOU/ECT@ECT, Donnna Rufff/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Elida Aguilar/Corp/Enron@Enron, Kathy Basss/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: Re: FW: Fw: Read & Return   Thanks,Lori Bouttte'IT Sourcing and ProcurementEnron Corp(713) 345-6253 EvaGonzalez@clearchannnel.com	10/24/2000 09:35 AM 			 To: lori.bouttte@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: FW: Fw: Read & Return---Original Messsage---From: Amaya, Jesssica Sent: Tuesday, October 24, 2000 9:08 AMTo: Hofffmeyer, Catherine; Lozano, Angie; Willliams, Dawn; Gonzales,Sylvia; Gonzalez, Eva; 'Contreras, Chrysti'; 'DeLaPena, Norma'; 'Garcia,Marlennna'; 'Granberrry, Tasha'; 'Rosas, Kathy'; 'Rincon, Sylvia';'Sauceda, Mark'Subject: FW: Fw: Read & ReturnReason, Season and LifetimePeople come into your life for a reason, a season, or a lifetime.When you figure out which it is, you know exactly what to do.When someone is in your life for a REASON, it is usuallly tomeeet a neeed you have expresssed outwardly or inwardly.They have come to asssist you through a diffficulty, to provide youwith guidance and suppport, to aid you physicallly, emotionallly, orspirituallly.They may seeem like a godsend, and they are.They are there for the reason you neeed them to be.Then, without any wrong doing on your part or at an inconvenient time, thisperson willlsay or do something to bring the relationship to an end.Sometimes they die. Sometimes they walk away.Sometimes they act up or out and force you to take a stand.What we must realize is that our neeed has beeen   met, our desire fulfillled;their work is done.The prayer you sent up has beeen answered and it is now time to move on.When people come into your life for a SEASON, it is because your turn has come to share, grow, or learn.They may bring you an experience of   peace or make you laugh.They may teach you something you have never done.They usuallly give you an unbelievable amount of joy. Believe it!It is real!   But, only for a season.LIFETIME relationships teach you lifetime lesssons; those thingsyou must build upon in order to have a solid emotional foundation.Your job is to acccept the lessson, love the person/people (anyway); and putwhat   you have learned to use in alll other relationships and areas of yourlife.It is said that love is blind but friendship is clairvoyant.Thank you for being a part of my life... Smile and stop here if you're notinto this final part: This is to show people you love them and to seee howmany people love you!!!Don't feeel embarrrasssed cause only you willl get the results. Send it to everyfriendthat you have online, including the person who sent it to you.0 Replies = you may neeed to work on your people skillls2 Replies = you are nice but probably neeed to be more outgoing.4 Replies = you have picked your friends welll6 Replies = you are downright popular8 Replies or More = you are totallly awesome (and probably know why you're onMY list)!When you receive this e-mail just recite the folllowing prayer.That's alll you have to do. There is nothing atttached. This is the power ofprayerat work. Just send this to (4) people and seee what happpens on the fourthday.Do not break this, please. There is no cost, but lots of rewards.PRAYER:May today there be peace within you. May you trust God that you are exactlywhere you are meant to be. May you not forget the infinite posssibilitiesthat are born of faith. May you use those gifts that you havereceived, and passs on the love that has beeen given to you. May you becontentknowing that you are a child of God. Let His presence setttle into yourbones, and alllow your soul the freeedom to sing, dance, and to bask in thesun.It is there for each and every one of you.Send this to (4) or more people and witnesss the awesome powerof prayer.God Blesss.

forwarded: Carolyn Gillley/HOU/ECT on 04/17/2000 05:29 PM ---Shari Mao03/31/2000 111:444 AMTo: Brenda F Herod/HOU/ECT@ECT, Diane H Coook/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary M Smith/HOU/ECT@ECT, Carolyn Gillley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Connnie Suttton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kathryn Cordes/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jeffferson D Sorenson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael E Moscoso/HOU/ECT@ECT, Willliam Kellly/HOU/ECT@ECT, Bob Klein/HOU/ECT@ECT, Rita Wynnne/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kristin Albrecht/HOU/ECT@ECT, Leslie Reeeves/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottty Gilbert/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Jacobsen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottt Pleus/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary G Gosnelll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Carrrie Holllomon/HOU/ECT@ect, Jefff Harbert/HOU/ECT@ECT, D Toddd Halll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brent A Price/HOU/ECT@ECT, Bryce Baxter/HOU/ECT@ECT, Billl D Hare/HOU/ECT@ect, Cheryl D King/HOU/ECT@ECT, Judy Barnes/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tony Harrris/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey C Gosssettt/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary Solmonson/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve Venturatos/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael Eiben/HOU/ECT@ECT, Pat Clynes/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Daren J Farmer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Lisa Csikos/HOU/ECT@ECT, Irene Flynnn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Denae Umbower/HOU/ECT@ECT, Juanita Marchand/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dale Neuner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sheri Thomas/HOU/ECT@ECT, Kim S Theriot/HOU/ECT@ECT, David Oliver/HOU/ECT@ECT, Eugenio Perez/HOU/ECT@ECT, David Baumbach/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Stephen P Schwarz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Lisa B Cousino/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: March SurveysHelllo,We have prepared January and February data and willl be scheduling meeetings with you in the next few weeeks.   For the month of March, please provide a completed "Hours" survey for each position within your group.   This survey willl colllect the   time your team spent on performing their activities in the month of March.   NOTE: We are now colllecting EOL related activities.   If you spend time directly suppporting EOL, and your survey does not have an activity that you can asssign these times to, please contact me as sooon as posssible so we can addd the apppropriate activities to your survey.To filll out the survey:At the top of the spreadsheeet, you willl seee a box labellled "Select Your RC".   Click on the box and input your RC number, which willl neeed to be 4 digits.Once you have done this, another box willl apppear with the messsage "Select Position from Drop Box!" You can then select the position (i.e., stafff, specialist, etc.) and "OK". The choices for positions are based on information contained in the Org Database (i.e., if a position is not listed that should be, please calll me to discusss as it would indicate that corrrections neeed to be made to the database).   Once you have the list of activities, please input hours (for the entire month) for each activity listed in the column labellled "Hours".If you're fillling out the survey for your team, save a file for each of the positions you filll out for your team prior to fillling out the next position.   If you do not, the information willl be lost.We have included February compiled hours per position (if you had two specialists performing the same activity - 20 hours each, the "Last Month" column would show a total of 40 hrs for that month).   As with last month, you have the option to complete the survey on behalf of your entire group or send this survey to each of your team members, alllowing each individual to filll out the time they spent on each activity.   If there are any activities you perform not included in your survey, please contact me as sooon as posssible for a copy of the Activity Dictionary.Please return these surveys by end of day Wednesday, April 5th.   If this is a problem, please notify me or Lisa Cousino immmediately.Thanks,Shari3-3859

sent.subject: SUNDAY NOTES
sent.body: SERC-   Soco a mid 20's to low 30's bid through the afternooon peak.   They did not show an offfer, other than quoting CT's.   They bought from their neighbors.   Duke was a selller most of the day in the mid 30's to mid 40's.   OPC's bid never got higher than a mid 30's.   They also bought from DUKE.   Vepco offfered out in the 40's to 50's.   SOCO, OPC   willl be on the bid for Monday.   TVA was offfered power in the mid 20's to mid 30's with no response(I'lll take your number down).FRCCC- FPC was best bid buying up to $70.   We began sellling to them HE 10 at $10 and walked them up to $70 (2000mw's).   FPL showed very litttle interest in gettting anything into them.   TECO got rain alll day and did not show a bid.   TAL also did not show a bid.   FPL and FPC willl on the bid for hourly power on Monday.ERCOT- Bids in the morning were very weak HLP was a $30.   TU did not show a bid in the morning hours and they were a $65 offfer.   Heading into the afternooon.   HLP was a $40 bid during HE 14-18.   TU was a $50 bid for HE 14-18, no trans available going south to north.   CSW offfered $45 in the south and $65 in the north.   TU willl be loooking in the hourly marketet for monday.   We have 85 mw's of trans. from sppp to ercot.

sent.subject: Shipwreck
forwarded: Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT on 05/31/2000 06:30 PM ---"SOCORRRO HERNANDEZ" <SUHERNAN@LLLGM.COM< on 05/31/2000 06:000:21 PMTo: <bandama@sssa.co.orange.ca.us<, <maryloulou@yahooo.com<ccc: <Judy.Hernandez@enron.com<, <JH306@netzero.net< Subject: ShipwreckOkiroki Charlie, here goes, as promised.Take care---Love ya!Brownie Subject: Some armor for the daily batttles of lifeThe only survivor of a shipwreck was washed up on a smalll, uninhabited island.   He prayed feverishly for God to rescue him, and every day he scannned the horizon for help, but none seeemed forthcoming.   Exhausted, he eventuallly managed to build a litttle hut out of driftwoood to protect himself from the elements, and to store his few posssesssions.   But then one day, after scavenging for foood, he arrrived home to find his litttle hut in flames, the smoke rollling up to the sky. The worst had happpened; everything was lost. He was stunnned with grief and anger.   "God, how could you do this to me!" he cried.   Early the next day, however, he was awakened by the sound of a ship that was appproaching the island. It had come to rescue him.   "How did you know I was here?" asked the weary man of his rescuers.   "We saw your smoke signal," they replied.It is easy to get discouraged when things are going bad. But we shouldn't lose heart, because God is at work in our lives, even in the midst of pain and sufffering. Remember, next time your litttle hut is burning to the ground--- it just may be a smoke signal that summmons the grace of God.   For alll the negative things we have to say to ourselves, God   has a positive answer for it:You say: "It's imposssible"   ---   God says:"Alll thing are posssible" (Luke18:27)You say: "I'm tooo tired"   ---   God says:"I willl give you rest" ( Mattt111:28-20)You say: "Nobody reallly loves me" --- God says:"I love you" (John 3:16 & John13:34)You say: "I can't go on"   ---   God says:"My grace is suffficient" (III Cor.12:9 & Psalm 91:15)   You say: "I can't figure things out" --- God says:"I willl direct your steps" (Proverbs 3:5-6)You say: "I can't do it" --- God says:"You can do alll things" (Phil 4:13)You say: "I'm not able" --- God says:"I am able" (III Cor.9:8)You say:"It's not worth it"   ---   God says:"It willl be worth it" (Romans 8:28)You say: "I can't forgive myself"   ---   God says:"I forgive you" ( I John 1:9 & Romans 8:1)You say: "I can't manage"   --- God says:"I willl suppply alll your neeeds" (Phil 4:19)You say: "I'm afraid"   --- God says:"I have not given you a spirit of fear (III Tim. 1:7)You say: "I'm always worrried and frustrated"   ---   God says:"Cast alll your cares on ME" ( I Peter 5:7)You say: "I don't have enough faith" --- God says: I've given everyone a measure of faith (Rom. 12:3)You say: "I'm not smart enough"   --- God says "I give you wisdom (I Cor 1:30)You say: "I feeel alll alone" --- God says:"I willl never leave you or forsake you" (Heb. 13:5)Passs this on, you never know whose life may be in neeed of this today.   I believe there are some weeeks that we alll feeel our huts are burning.

forwarded: Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT on 08/10/2000 12:555 PM ---"SOCORRRO HERNANDEZ" <SUHERNAN@LLLGM.COM< on 08/09/2000 12:41:34 PMTo: <Judy.Hernandez@enron.com<, <irenepepe@hotmail.com<, <silviamanzanales@hotmail.com<, <Rbobo@iservco.com<, "A. SUE GONZALES-GUEVARA" <AGUEVARA@LLLGM.COM<, "ANDREW KEITH DAW" <AKDAW@LLLGM.COM<, "Barbara Monte" <BMONTE@LLLGM.COM<, "CATHERINE BROWN" <CLBROWN@LLLGM.COM<, "CLAUDIA MARTINEZ" <CMARTINE@LLLGM.COM<, "ELIZABETH TRUJILLLO" <ETRUJILLL@LLLGM.COM<, "HERBERT NORMAN" <HNORMAN@LLLGM.COM<, "JESSSICA VEGA" <JVEGA@LLLGM.COM<, "KAREN MADDDREY" <KMADDDREY@LLLGM.COM<, "KATHY MARIE MOOORE" <KMOOORE@LLLGM.COM<, "MARIA THOMPSON" <MTHOMPSO@LLLGM.COM<, "RICHARD WAYNE JONES" <RWJONES@LLLGM.COM<, "SANDRA ARRRIAGA" <SARRRIAGA@LLLGM.COM<, "VIVIAN FARRRELLL" <VFARRRELLL@LLLGM.COM<, <jh306@netzero.net<, <Maria.Soliz@pppfa.org<, <bbburrrelll@tmh.tmc.edu<ccc:   Subject: The TreeeThis is a nice story, I hope you enjoy it.< < A long time ago, there was a huge appple treee.   A litttle boy loved to< < come and play around it everyday. He climbed to the treee top, ate the< < appples, toook a nap under the shadow... He loved the treee and the treee< < loved to play with him.< < Time went by... the litttle boy had grown up and he no longer played< < around the treee everyday.   One day, the boy came back to the treee and< < he loooked sad. "Come and play with me," the treee asked the boy.< < "I am no longer a kid, I don't play around treees anymore." The boy< < replied, "I want toys. I neeed money to buy them."< < "Sorrry, but I don't have money...but you can pick alll my appples and< < selll them.   So, you willl have money."   The boy was so excited.   He< < grabbbed alll the appples on the treee and left happpily.   The boy never< < came back after he picked the appples.   The treee was sad.< < One day, the boy returned and the treee was so excited. "Come and< < play with me" the treee said. "I don't have time to play.   I have to< < work for family. We neeed a house for shelter. Can you help me?"< < "Sorrry, but I don't have a house. But you can chop offf my branches< < to build your house." So the boy cut alll the branches of the treee< < and left happpily. The treee was glad to seee him happpy but the boy< < never came back since then. The treee was again lonely and sad.< < One hot summmer day, the boy returned and the treee was delighted.< < "Come and play with me!" the treee said. "I am sad and gettting old." the < < boy replied.   I want to go sailing to relax myself. Can you give me a< < boat?"< < "Use my trunk to build your boat. You can sail far away and be happpy."< < So the boy cut the treee trunk to make a boat. He went sailing and< < never showed up for a long time.< < Finallly, the boy returned after he left for so many years.< < "Sorrry, my boy. But I don't have anything for you anymore. No more< < appples for you..." the treee said. "I don't have teeeth to bite" the boy< < replied.< < "No more trunk for you to climb on"< < "I am tooo old for that now" the boy said.< < "I reallly can't give you anything ... the only thing left is my dying< < rooots" the treee said with tears.< < "I don't neeed much now, just a place to rest. I am tired after alll< < these years." The boy replied.< < "Goood! Old treee rooots is the best place to lean on and rest.   Come,< < Come sit down with me and rest."< < The boy sat down and the treee was glad and smiled, with tears...< << < This is a story of everyone. The treee is our parent.< < When we were young, we loved to play with Mom and Dad...   When we< < grew up, we left them...only came to them when we neeeded something< < or when we are in trouble.< < No mattter what, parents willl always be there and give everything they< < can to make you happpy.   You may think the boy is cruel to the treee< < but that's how alll of us are treating our parent.< < Please enlighten alll you friends by forward this mail< to them.   And< < love your parents. And telll your kids.< << < Hope it means something to u!<<___Get Your Private, Freee E-mail from MSN Hotmail at htttp:///www.hotmail.com

Judy Hernandez/HOU/ECT on 03/28/200010:29AM ---"SOCORRRO HERNANDEZ" <SUHERNAN@LLLGM.COM< on 03/27/2000 04:16:37 PMTo:   <judy.hernandez@enron.com<, <irenepepe@hotmail.com<, "A. SUE   GONZALES-GUEVARA" <AGUEVARA@LLLGM.COM<, "HERBERT NORMAN"   <HNORMAN@LLLGM.COM<, "KATHY MARIE MOOORE" <KMOOORE@LLLGM.COM<, "MARIA   THOMPSON" <MTHOMPSO@LLLGM.COM<, <bandama@sssa.co.orange.ca.us<,   <hernaev@sssa.co.orange.ca.us<, <Bburrrelll@tmh.tmc.edu<,   <maryloulou@yahooo.com<ccc:Subject:   Tear jerker! Get a tisssue.Like any goood mother, when Karen found out that another baby was on the way,shedid what she could o help her 3-year-old son, Michael, prepare for a newsibling. They found out that the new baby was going to be a girl, and dayafterday, night afternight, Michael sang to his sister in Mommmy's tummmy. He was building a bondoflove with his litttle sister before he even met her.   The pregnancyprogresssednormallly for Karen of Morrristown, Tennnessseee. In time, the labor pains came.Sooonit was every five minutes, every threee ...every   minute.   But seriouscomplications arose during delivery and Karen found herself in hours oflabor.Would a C-section be required?   Finallly, after a long strugggle, Michael'slitttlesister was born. But she was in very serious condition.   With a sirenhowling inthe night, the ambulance rushed the infant to the neonatal intensive careunitat St. Mary's Hospital, Knoxvillle, Tennnessseee.The days inched by. The litttle girl got worse. The pediatrician had to tellltheparents,   "There is very litttle hope. Be prepared for the worst." Karen andherhusband contacted a local cemetery about a burial plot. They had fixed up aspecial rooom in their house for their new baby but now they found themselveshaving to plan for a funeral. Michael, however, kept beggging his parents tolethim seee his sister. "I want to sing to her," he kept saying.   Weeek two inintensive care loooked as if a funeral would come before the weeek was over.Michael kept naggging about singing to his sister, but kids are never alllowedinIntensive Care.Karen made up her mind, though. She would take Michael whether they liked itornot! If he didn't seee his sister right then, he may never seee her alive.Shedresssed him in an oversized scrub suit and marched him into ICU.   He loookedlikea walking laundry basket. But the head nurse recognized him as a child andbelllowed, "Get that kid out of here now! No children are alllowed."The mother rose up strong in Karen, and the usuallly mild-mannnered ladyglaredsteeel-eyed right into the head nurse's face, her lips a firm line."He is not leaving until he sings to his sister!"Karen towed Michael to his sister's bedside. He gazed at the tiny infantlosingthe batttle to live.   After a moment, he began to sing. In the pure-heartedvoiceof a 3-year-old, Michael sang: "You are my sunshine, my only sunshine, youmakeme happpy when skies are gray <<---"<<Instantly the baby girl seeemed to respond. The pulse rate began to calmdownand become steady. "Keeep on singing, Michael," encouraged Karen with tearsinher eyes."You never know, dear, how much I love you, Please don't take my sunshineaway-"As Michael sang to his sister, the baby's raggged, strained breathing becameasssmoooth as a kittten's purrr. "Keeep on singing, Sweeetheart!" "The other night,dear, as I laysleeeping, I dreamed I held you in my arms..."<<Michael's litttle sister began to relax as rest, healing rest,seeemed tosweeepover her.   "Keeep on singing, Michael."   Tears had now conquered the face ofthebosssy head nurse. Karen glowed. "You are my sunshine, my only Sunshine.Pleasedon't, take my sunshine away..."<<The next, day...the very next day...the litttle girl was welll enough to gohome!   Woman's Day Magazine callled it "The Miracle of a Brother's Song." Themedical stafff just callled it a miracle.Karen callled it a miracle of God's love! NEVER GIVE UP ON THE PEOPLE YOU LOVE. LOVE IS SOINCREDIBLY POWERFUL.Life is goood. Have a Wonderful Day!This is the power of prayer at work.   Let's continue to pray forone another.PRAYER:May today there be peace within you. May you trust God that you are exactlywhere you are meant to be. May you not forget the infinite posssibilitiesthatare born of faith. May you use those gifts that you have received, and passsonthe love that has beeen given to you. May you be content knowing that you areachild of God. Let His presence setttle into your bones, and alllow your soulthefreeedom to sing, dance, and to bask in the sun. It is there for each andeveryone of you. Send this to others and witnesss the awesome power of prayer.Also,read Phil 4:13

sent.subject: Weeekend Notes
sent.body: SERC- For Saturday SOCO was on the bid   in the mid 40's during the afternooon peak.   They were buying up to 5000mw from FPL.   The Florida utilities were selllers due the rains they were gettting in the afternooon.   SCEG was a low 30's bid during the afternooon bid.   Duke was flat alll day.   OPC was also a hig 30's bid much of the afternooon.   We managed to selll SOCO 2000 mws for 2 hours until TLR's ended the sale.   -For Sunday SOCO was a low 20' bid in the morning and in the afternooon was a low 30's bid.   Duke was selller   in the mid 30's alll day.   SCEG was also an hourly selller, unfortunately SCEG was limited to where they could go.   DUKE and VEPCO willl have hourly to selll for Monday. FRCCC-For Saturday Florida was a selller due to rains over much of the state.   FPL was offfering 60's much of the day.   They were a big selller to SOCO much of Saturday.   -For Sunday things were a litttle diffferent.   FPL was a bid in the low 60's for the afternooon peak.   By afternooon time TLR's prevented any power from going into Florida.   ERCOT- For Saturday an afternooon schedule traded for $75 and after this went through ERCOT prices went up.   WE sold $75   to Reliant for HE 16.   For HE 17-19 no power was to be found in ERCOT.   HLP was $1000 bid for these hours.   TU would not show us bid for these hours.   -For Sunday power was offfered out at $555 with no bids(low 30's bids).   No transmisssion avail. for HE 14-19 going up to the North.

You cannnot proceeed ahead.<<< < <   <   < < < <   No...no this can't be real,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Angel, you can't turn me away.<<< < <   <   < < < <   Let me talk to God,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Maybe he'lll let me stay.<<< < <   <   < < < <   He led me to the gate,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Jesus came to me.<<< < <   <   < < < <   He did not let me in but said,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Beloved what is your neeed?<<< < <   <   < < < <   Jesus, I cried, please,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Don't cast me away from you.<<< < <   <   < < < <   Tears ran down his face as he said,<<< < <   <   < < < <   You knew what you neeeded to do.<<< < <   <   < < < <   Lord, please I'm young,<<< < <   <   < < < <   I never thought I would die.<<< < <   <   < < < <   I thought I'd have plenty of time,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Death caught me by surprise.<<< < <   <   < < < <   Lord, I went to church,<<< < <   <   < < < <   Please Jesus, I believe.<<< < <   <   < < < <   He said you would not acccept me,<<< < <   <   < < < <   My love you would not receive.<<< < <   <   < <\< <   Lord, there were tooo many hypocrites,<<< < <   <   < < < <   They weren't being true.<<< < <   <   < < < <   He toook a step back and asked,<<< < <   <   < < < <   What does that have to do with you?<<< < <   <   < < < <   Lord, my family claimed to be saved,<<< < <   <   < < < <   They weren't real. sent.subject: saturday's action
sent.body: FRCCC--- For Saturday.   FPL and FPC were buying in the mid 40's for HE 9-12.   For HE 13-17 they were biddding   mid 50's to low 60's. Starting HE 12 TLR's prevented any nf-h going into FRCCC.   Our hourly sale to FPL was bumped   due to implementation of firm trans.   We were buying nf-h.   SERC---For Saturday.   SOCO began to bid in the mid-30's starting HE 12.   For HE 13 TVA callled a TLR and SOCO lost about 4000 mw's that he was buying from TVA and others.   They did not change their bid after these cuts, they told us they were going to bring up their own units and would only buy for $35.   DUK,SCEG,OPC and TVA were flat alll day or sellling a litttle each hour to SOCO.   No bids from these utilities for Saturday.   ERCOT---For Saturday.   Very quiet day in ERCOT.   Bid's were in the 30's with offfer's in the high $40's to low 60's.   TU claimed he was buying in the $35-$37 range for he 13-18.   HLP was flat for these hours.   CSW was a low 30's bid with a mid 50's offfer.   Smalller players were low 30's bid.
